questions.text: Congenital Lactic acidosis is due to the defect of
questions.solution:
Congenital lactic acidosis is primarily caused by defects in pyruvate metabolism, especially in pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH). PDH is a key enzyme that converts pyruvate to acetyl-CoA, linking glycolysis to the citric acid cycle.

When PDH is deficient or defective, pyruvate accumulates and is shunted to lactate production, leading to lactic acidosis. This condition presents with neurological symptoms due to impaired energy production in the brain.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A) Transketolase

  • Function: Transketolase is an enzyme in the pentose phosphate pathway (PPP) that helps in nucleotide synthesis and NADPH production.
  • Deficiency Association: Often linked to thiamine (Vitamin B1) deficiency, seen in Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome but not directly related to congenital lactic acidosis.

Choice B) Branched-Chain Ketoacid Dehydrogenase (BCKDH)

  • Function: BCKDH is responsible for breaking down branched-chain amino acids (leucine, isoleucine, valine) into their respective keto acids.
  • Deficiency Association: Causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), leading to accumulation of branched-chain keto acids rather than lactic acidosis.

Choice C) Isocitrate Dehydrogenase (IDH)

  • Function: IDH is a key enzyme in the TCA (Krebs) cycle, converting isocitrate to α-ketoglutarate while producing NADH.
  • Deficiency Association: IDH mutations are linked to certain cancers (e.g., gliomas, AML) but not congenital lactic acidosis.

Key Takeaway

  • Congenital lactic acidosis is primarily due to a defect in pyruvate dehydrogenase (PDH), leading to impaired energy metabolism and excessive lactate production.
  • Neurological symptoms are common due to ATP deficiency in the brain.
  • Other enzyme defects listed do not directly cause congenital lactic acidosis but are associated with distinct metabolic disorders.

questions.text: Which is not a product of heme catabolism
questions.solution:
Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) - NOT a Product of Heme Catabolism

ALA is a precursor in heme synthesis, not its breakdown. It is formed in the mitochondria from glycine and succinyl-CoA in the first step of heme biosynthesis, catalyzed by ALA synthase.

Incorrect choices explanation :

Choice A) Ferric ion (Fe³+) - Product of Heme Catabolism. Heme degradation begins with the enzyme heme oxygenase, which breaks down heme into biliverdin, carbon monoxide (CO), and free iron (Fe²+). The released Fe²+ is quickly oxidized to Fe³+ (ferric ion) and stored as ferritin or transported by transferrin.

Choice C) Biliverdin - Product of Heme Catabolism. Heme is first broken down by heme oxygenase into biliverdin. Biliverdin is then converted into bilirubin by the enzyme biliverdin reductase.

Choice D) Carbon monoxide (CO) - Product of Heme Catabolism. Heme oxygenase activity results in the release of CO, which serves as a signaling molecule and has vasodilatory effects.

Key Takeaway

Aminolevulinic acid (ALA) is not a product of heme catabolism; it is a precursor in heme biosynthesis.

  • Heme catabolism produces ferric ion (Fe³+), biliverdin, and carbon monoxide.
  • ALA is synthesized from glycine and succinyl-CoA in the first step of heme biosynthesis.

questions.text: Match the following
Inhibitor A and B are
questions.solution:
Reversibly Competitive inhibition is when the inhibitor binds to the substrate-binding Site and competes with the substrate for the active enzyme-binding site. This effect of competitive inhibition can be overcome by increasing the substrate concentration by which maximum velocity can still be achieved. Therefore, Vmax is unaltered in this type of inhibition. However, the concentration of the substrate required to achieve half of the maximum velocity is increased. Therefore, Km is increased in this condition.

Non-competitive inhibition is by binding inhibitors to enzymes in locations other than the active site. Increasing the concentration of the substrate does not overcome non-competitive inhibition Thus noncompetitive inhibitors decrease the Vmax of the reaction. They do not interfere with the binding of the substrate to the enzyme. Thus, the enzyme shows the same Km in the presence or absence of noncompetitive inhibitors.

Uncompetitive inhibition is a type of enzyme inhibition in which the inhibitor can only bind to the enzyme-substrate complex. As a result, uncompetitive inhibition Vmax decreases but it does not change the affinity of the enzyme for the substrate. the inhibitors typically bind to an allosteric site on the enzyme which changes the shape of the enzyme and makes it more difficult for the substrate to bind.

For example, the drug methotrexate is an uncompetitive inhibitor of dihydrofolate reductase, an enzyme that is involved in the synthesis of DNA.

Suicidal inhibition, also known as irreversible inhibition or mechanism-based inhibition, is a type of enzyme inhibition in which the inhibitor irreversibly binds to the active site of the enzyme, causing permanent inactivation.

Key Takeaway

  • Inhibitor A is Non-Competitive, and Inhibitor B is Competitive.
  • Competitive inhibition: Inhibitor binds to the active site, increasing Km but not affecting Vmax.
  • Non-competitive inhibition: Inhibitor binds to an allosteric site, decreasing Vmax but not affecting Km.

questions.text: Which gene defect causes Familial hypercholesterolemia
questions.solution:
The LDL receptor is defective in familial hypercholesterolemia, a genetic

condition in which blood LDL cholesterol levels are increased, causing premature atherosclerosis

Apo lipoproteins carry out several roles:

  1. they can form part of the structure of the lipoprotein, for example, apo B;
  2. they are enzyme cofactors, for example, C-II for lipoprotein lipase, A-I for lecithin:cholesterol acyltransferase (LCAT), or enzyme inhibitors, for example, apo A-II and apo C-III for lipoprotein lipase, apo C-I for cholesteryl ester transfer protein
  3. they act as ligands for interaction with lipoprotein receptors in tissues, for example, apo B-100 and apo E for the LDL receptor, apo E for the LDL-receptor-related protein-1 (LRP-1), which recognizes remnant lipoproteins (see later), and apo A-I for the HDL receptor.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A : Apo E

Apolipoprotein E (ApoE) is involved in the metabolism of lipoproteins, particularly in the clearance of chylomicron and VLDL remnants by the liver. Defects in ApoE are associated with Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (familial dysbetalipoproteinemia), not familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).A major function of HDL is to act as a repository for the apo C and apo E required in the metabolism of chylomicrons and VLDL

Choice B : Apo C2

Apolipoprotein C-II (ApoC-II) is a cofactor for lipoprotein lipase (LPL), an enzyme responsible for breaking down triglyceride-rich lipoproteins like chylomicrons and VLDL. A defect in ApoC-II leads to familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia), characterized by severe hypertriglyceridemia, not hypercholesterolemia.

Choice D : Apo B48

Apolipoprotein B-48 (ApoB-48) is involved in chylomicron formation and transport, playing a role in dietary fat absorption. It is not related to LDL metabolism or familial hypercholesterolemia. Instead, ApoB-100 mutations (not B-48) are associated with FH, but LDL receptor defects are the primary cause

Key Takeaway

  • Familial hypercholesterolemia (FH) is caused by a defect in the LDL receptor gene, leading to impaired clearance of LDL cholesterol and premature atherosclerosis.
  • ApoE defects → Type III hyperlipoproteinemia (familial dysbetalipoproteinemia)
  • ApoC-II defects → Familial chylomicronemia syndrome (Type I hyperlipoproteinemia)
  • ApoB-48 → Involved in chylomicron transport, not LDL metabolism or FH.

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not an amino acid derivative?
questions.solution:
Neurotransmitters derived from aminoacids include γ-aminobutyrate (GABA), 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin), dopamine, norepinephrine, and epinephrine. Glycine, Arginine and Methionine participate in Creatine Synthesis.

Decarboxylation of histidine to histamine is catalyzed by the pyridoxal 5′-phosphate-dependent enzyme histidine decarboxylase.

Following hydroxylation of tryptophan to 5-hydroxytryptophan by liver tryptophan hydroxylase subsequent decarboxylation forms serotonin (5-hydroxytryptamine), a

potent vasoconstrictor and stimulator of smooth muscle contraction

GABA functions in brain tissue as an inhibitory neurotransmitter by altering transmembrane potential differences. GABA is formed by decarboxylation of glutamate by l-glutamate decarboxylase.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Histamine (A) - Amino Acid Derivative

  • Formed by decarboxylation of histidine via histidine decarboxylase.
  • Functions as a neurotransmitter in the brain and is also involved in immune responses, vasodilation, and gastric acid secretion.

Serotonin (B) - Amino Acid Derivative

  • Synthesized from tryptophan through hydroxylation and decarboxylation.
  • Acts as a neurotransmitter involved in mood regulation, appetite control, and sleep-wake cycles.

GABA (C) - Amino Acid Derivative

  • γ-Aminobutyric acid (GABA) is derived from glutamate through decarboxylation.
  • Acts as the main inhibitory neurotransmitter in the central nervous system, reducing neuronal excitability.

Key Takeaway

  • Amino acid-derived neurotransmitters include histamine (from histidine), serotonin (from tryptophan), and GABA (from glutamate).
  • Creatine is not a neurotransmitter but a high-energy phosphate carrier synthesized from glycine, arginine, and methionine.

questions.text:
The interpretation of the following ABG values is?
pH = 7.34
Na = 135 mEq/L
Cl = 93 mEq/L
HCO3 = 20mEq/L
questions.solution:
Above Arterial Blood gas analysis

pH - 7.34 suggestive of Acidosis

Calculation of Anion Gap = 135 - (93+ 3) = 39 suggestive of High Anion Gap (Normal - 12 +/- 4 mmol/L)

As low HCO3 value suggestive of Metabolic Cause

Diagnosis - High Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Acidosis (B)

  • In normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA), the anion gap remains within the normal range (8–16 mEq/L).
  • Here, the anion gap is elevated (22), so this is incorrect.

High Anion Gap Metabolic Alkalosis (C)

  • Alkalosis would require pH > 7.45, but the pH here is 34 (acidotic).
  • Also, metabolic alkalosis is associated with elevated bicarbonate (HCO3- > 28 mEq/L), but in this case, it is low (20 mEq/L).

Normal Anion Gap Metabolic Alkalosis (D)

  • Same reasoning as option C-pH is acidic and HCO3- is low, ruling out metabolic alkalosis.
  • A normal anion gap in this scenario would be associated with hyperchloremic acidosis rather than alkalosis.

Key Takeaway

  • Metabolic acidosis is confirmed by a low HCO3- and pH < 7.35.
  • Anion gap > 16 suggests high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA), commonly seen in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), lactic acidosis, uremia, or toxic ingestions (e.g., methanol, ethylene glycol).

questions.text:
What is the interpretation of the following ABG value?
pH = 7.5
Pco2 = 50 mmhg
HCO3 = 30 mEq/L
questions.solution:
• The high pH (7.5) indicates alkalosis.
  • The elevated HCO3- (30 mEq/L) suggests a primary metabolic alkalosis.
  • The increased Pco2 (50 mmHg) indicates partial respiratory compensation, meaning the body is trying to retain CO2 to lower the pH back toward normal.

Possible Causes of Metabolic Alkalosis:

  • Loss of acid: Vomiting, nasogastric suctioning
  • Excess bicarbonate: Overuse of antacids, bicarbonate administration
  • Volume contraction alkalosis: Diuretics (loop/thiazides)

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Metabolic Acidosis (A)

  • Would require a low pH (<7.35) and low HCO3-, but here, both pH and bicarbonate are elevated, ruling this out.

Respiratory Acidosis (C)

  • Would be characterized by low pH (<7.35) and high Pco2 (>45 mmHg) due to CO2 retention.
  • Although Pco2 is elevated, the pH is alkalotic, not acidotic, ruling out respiratory acidosis.

Respiratory Alkalosis (D)

  • Would present with high pH and low Pco2 (<35 mmHg) due to excessive CO2 elimination (e.g., hyperventilation).
  • Here, Pco2 is high, not low, confirming that the primary disorder is not respiratory.

Key Takeaway

  • Metabolic alkalosis is diagnosed when both pH and HCO3- are elevated.
  • Compensatory respiratory acidosis (high Pco2) suggests the lungs are attempting to retain CO2 to counteract alkalosis.
  • Common causes include vomiting, nasogastric suctioning, diuretic use, and excessive bicarbonate intake.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with post transcriptional modification?
questions.solution:
Pre mRNA components of Heterogeneous nuclear RNA undergo extensive co and post transcriptional modification in the nucleus and become mature mRNA.

The modification includes 1) Addition of a 5'Cap. The cap is a 7-methylguanosine attached to the 5' terminal end of the mRNA through unusual 5'-5' triphosphate linkage.

Creation of the cap requires removal of the y-phosphoryl group from the 5' triphosphate of the pre mRNA followed by addition of guanosine monophosphate by the nuclear enzyme Guanyltransferase.

14 nucleotide intron in the anticodon loop is removed by nuclease.

Methylation of this terminal guanine occurs in the cytosol and is catalyzed by guanine 7 methyltransferase.

  • Adenosylmethionine is the source of the methyl group.

Glycosylation is not the process in Post transcriptional modification.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Methylation (A)

  • Methylation of mRNA (e.g., m7G capping at the 5' end) is a key post-transcriptional modification.
  • Other methylation events, such as N6-methyladenosine (m6A) modification, influence mRNA stability and translation.

Endonuclease Cleavage (B)

  • In post-transcriptional processing, endonucleases remove introns from pre-mRNA via splicing.
  • Cleavage is also required for the maturation of rRNA and tRNA molecules.

5' Capping (C)

  • The addition of a 7-methylguanosine (m7G) cap to the 5' end of mRNA is a crucial post-transcriptional modification.
  • It protects mRNA from degradation and is essential for ribosome recognition during translation.

Key Takeaway

  • Post-transcriptional modifications include 5' capping, splicing, polyadenylation, and methylation to process pre-mRNA into mature mRNA.
  • Glycosylation is a post-translational modification that occurs after translation in proteins, not during RNA processing.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiency is associated with sexual maturation defect and hypogonadism?
questions.solution:
Human Body contain more than 3000 Zn containing metalloproteins majority are transcription factors and DNA , RNA Binding proteins known as Zinc Finger. Zn is essential components of several metalloenzymes like Carboxypeptidase A, Carbonic Anydrase II, Adenosine Deaminase, Alkaline Phosphate Phospholipase C, Leucine Aminopeptidase and alcohol dehydrogenase.

Zinc plays a crucial role in growth, immune function, and reproductive health. Severe deficiency can lead to delayed puberty, hypogonadism, and impaired spermatogenesis.

Incorrect choices explanation:

Choice A) Selenium: Important for thyroid function but not directly linked to hypogonadism.

Choice C) Copper (Cu): Deficiency can cause neurological symptoms and anemia but not significant sexual maturation defects.

Choice D) Iron: Primarily affects red blood cell production and energy levels rather than sexual maturation.

Key Takeaway

  • Zinc deficiency is directly linked to hypogonadism and delayed puberty due to its role in hormone regulation and spermatogenesis.
  • Other trace elements (selenium, copper, iron) have metabolic and physiological functions but do not primarily affect sexual maturation.

choices.text: Frame shift mutation of coding gene

questions.text: Which type of mutation results in the reversal to the wild type of phenotype when the mutant gene is suppressed?
questions.solution:
Mutation results when changes occur in the nucleotide sequence. Single Base Changes also known as Point Mutation may be transition or Transversion. When the DNA nucleotide sequence of a protein coding gene containing mutation is transcribed into an mRNA molecule then the RNA molecule will of course possess the base change at the corresponding location.

Frameshift Mutation results from Deletion or insertion of Nucleotides in DNA that generates Altered mRNAs.

Altered protein Products of gene mutation is based on the presence of Normally functioning tRNA molecules. Abnormally functioning tRNA molecules themselves are the results of mutation. Mutation of tRNA are capable of binding to and decoding altered codons thereby suppressing the effect of mutation in distinct mutated mRNA encoding structural genes. These suppressor tRNA molecules usually formed as a result of alternation in their anticodon regions are capable of suppressing certain Missense mutation, nonsense mutation, and frameshift mutation.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Frame Shift Mutation of Coding Gene (Choice A)

  • A frameshift mutation alters the reading frame, leading to a completely different protein sequence.
  • This does not suppress the original mutation but introduces a new defect.

Addition of Another Normal Gene (Choice B)

  • Introducing a normal gene can compensate for the defective one (gene therapy) but does not revert the original mutant gene.
  • This is a genetic complementation, not suppression.

Deletion of the Mutant Gene (Choice C)

  • Removing the mutant gene may prevent defective protein synthesis but does not restore wild-type function unless a functional copy is present elsewhere.
  • This approach is more related to gene knockout rather than suppression.

Key Takeaway

  • Suppressor tRNA mutations can counteract specific genetic mutations by modifying codon recognition, restoring normal protein synthesis and function.

questions.text: Which diagnostic tool is preferred for metabolic disease screening in children?
questions.solution:
Tandem Mass Spectrometry helps ins analysis of Complex Peptide Mixtures without prior Purification also known as MS- MS. The first Mass Spectrometer separates individual peptides based on their differences in Mass. By Adjusting the field strength of the first magnet, single peptide can be directed into the second mass spectrometer, where fragments are generated and their masses determined.

Tandem MS can be used to screen blood samples from newborns for the presence and concentration of amino acids, fatty acids and other metabolites.

Abnormalities in metabolite levels can serve as diagnostic indicators for a variety of genetic disorders such as Phenylketonuria.

Completed blood count can not help in diagnosis of Metabolic disease screening and the same way urine analysis.

Genetic testing can be done to confirm metabolic abnormalities but not as a primary tool for diagnosis of Inborn error of Metabolism.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice B: Complete Blood Count - Limited to Blood Cell Abnormalities
A complete blood count (CBC) provides information about red and white blood cells and platelets. While useful for diagnosing anemia and infections, it does not assess metabolic enzyme deficiencies or abnormal metabolite levels, making it unsuitable for metabolic disease screening.

Choice C: Urine Analysis - Detects Renal and Systemic Abnormalities, Not Metabolic Diseases
Urine analysis primarily helps in detecting kidney disease, infections, and systemic conditions such as diabetes. Though some metabolic disorders may present with abnormal urine findings (e.g., maple syrup urine disease), urine analysis alone is not a primary screening tool for metabolic disorders.

Choice D: Genetic Testing - Used for Confirmatory Diagnosis, Not Initial Screening
Genetic testing identifies mutations in metabolic disease-related genes but is not typically used for initial screening due to its high cost and time requirements. Instead, it is employed for confirmation after abnormal metabolic screening results.

Key Takeaway

Tandem Mass Spectrometry is the preferred method for metabolic disease screening in children because it allows for rapid and comprehensive detection of multiple metabolic abnormalities, enabling early diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: FISH is used to detect all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Fluorescence in situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that uses fluorescent probes to bind to specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. The probes are labeled with fluorescent dyes that emit different colors of light. When the probes bind to the DNA, they can be seen under a fluorescent microscope.

The FISH technique is used to detect and localize specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It is used to detect

Chromosome abnormalities (Aneuploidy - Down syndrome, Turner syndrome, and Klinefelter syndrome )

Microdeletions and rearrangements (Prader-Willi syndrome, Angelman syndrome, and Williams syndrome)

Gene Amplification(cancers, including breast cancer and neuroblastoma)

Complex Translocations (chronic myeloid leukemia and Burkitt lymphoma)

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Translocation - Detectable by FISH
FISH is widely used to identify chromosomal translocations, which occur when chromosome segments are rearranged between non-homologous chromosomes. It is commonly used in diagnosing cancers like chronic myeloid leukemia (CML), where the BCR-ABL translocation (Philadelphia chromosome) is detected.

Choice B: Amplification - Detectable by FISH
FISH can detect gene amplification, which is an increase in the number of copies of a specific gene. This is useful in cancer diagnosis, such as detecting HER2 gene amplification in breast cancer, which guides targeted therapy decisions.

Choice C: Deletion - Detectable by FISH
FISH can identify chromosomal deletions, including microdeletions that may not be visible on standard karyotyping. It is used to diagnose conditions such as Prader-Willi syndrome, Angelman syndrome, and Williams syndrome, which result from small chromosomal deletions.

Key Takeaway

FISH is effective for detecting large-scale chromosomal abnormalities such as translocations, amplifications, and deletions, but it cannot detect point mutations, which require molecular techniques like PCR or sequencing.

choices.text: Low homocysteine and high methylmalonic acid
B12 supplementation is recommended along with folate
Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected

questions.text: In folate deficiency the truth statement is?
questions.solution:
Active Form of Folic Acid is THFA. For formation of THFA Vitamin B12 is required or else Folic Acid will be trapped in Methyl THFA and not used for its biological actions.

As In folate Deficiency, transfer of the formimino group is impaired, and Figlu is excreted. Excretion of Figlu following a dose of histidine thus can be used to detect folic acid deficiency.

When acting as a methyl donor, S-adenosyl methionine forms homocysteine, which may be methyltetrahydrofolate by methionine synthase, a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme. So Homocysteine level is increased along with increased level of Methyl Malonic acid in urine. So Vitamin B12 deficiency will also lead to folate trap. Thus Vitamin B12 Supplementation is recommended along with folate.

In absence of Folic Acid & THFA formation, which is involved in one carbon metabolism also affects Vitamin B12 level. As folic acid also involved in Purine Nucleotide synthesis as N10 Formyl THF. Absence of its leads to inability of cells to make DNA, protein synthesis continue. . This will affects rapidly developing cells like bone marrow and RBC leading to Macrocytosis &- Megaloblastic Anemia.

Incorrect Choices Explanation

Choice A: Low homocysteine and high methylmalonic acid - Incorrect
Folate deficiency leads to an increase in homocysteine levels because folate is required for the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine. However, methylmalonic acid (MMA) levels remain normal in folate deficiency because MMA metabolism depends on vitamin B12, not folate. In contrast, vitamin B12 deficiency causes both elevated homocysteine and MMA levels.

Choice B: Hemolytic anemia is a feature - Incorrect
Folate deficiency primarily causes megaloblastic anemia, which results from impaired DNA synthesis, leading to large, immature red blood cells. Hemolytic anemia, which involves increased destruction of RBCs, is not a primary feature of folate deficiency.

Choice D: Purine and pyrimidine synthesis are affected - Incorrect
Folate plays a key role in DNA synthesis by participating in one-carbon metabolism for purine (via N10-formyl-THF) and pyrimidine (via N5, N10-methylene-THF) synthesis. However, in folate deficiency, pyrimidine synthesis can still proceed, while purine synthesis is more severely impaired. This makes this statement incomplete as the primary issue is purine synthesis rather than both purine and pyrimidine equally.

Key Takeaway

Folate deficiency leads to increased homocysteine levels, megaloblastic anemia, and impaired DNA synthesis. Vitamin B12 supplementation is recommended alongside folate to prevent masking of underlying B12 deficiency, which can lead to irreversible neurological damage.

questions.text:
Korsakoff psychosis all are true except?
1) Amnesia
2) Confabulation
3) Ophthalmoplegia
4) Neuropathy
questions.solution:
Thiamine deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes:

  • a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi, which may or may not be associated with heart failure and edema;
  • acute pernicious (fulminating) beriberi (Shoshin beriberi), in which heart failure and metabolic abnormalities predominate, without peripheral neuritis;
  • Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis, which is associated especially with

alcohol and narcotic abuse.

The role of thiamine diphosphate in pyruvate dehydrogenase means that in deficiency there is impaired conversion of pyruvate to acetyl -CoA which plays a key role in energy metabolism of cells particularly in tissues of the CNS. Thiamine Deficiency resulting in decreased ATP production and therefore impaired cellular function.

In Korsakoff Psychosis - mental confusion, gait ataxia, nystagmus and ophthalmoplegia , dementia is seen.

Key Takeaway

Korsakoff psychosis is characterized primarily by amnesia, confabulation, and executive dysfunction, but ophthalmoplegia is a feature of Wernicke encephalopathy, not classic Korsakoff syndrome.
